title: Lesson 15: Quick Eigenvalue Computation
lesson_title: A quick trick for computing eigenvalues
objectives: Use trace and determinant to find 2×2 eigenvalues quickly

cards.front: What is the trace of a matrix?
cards.back:
The sum of the diagonal entries.

For a 2×2 matrix \( \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \): \( \text{trace} = a + d \)

cards.front: How does the trace relate to eigenvalues?
cards.back:
The trace equals the sum of the eigenvalues.

For a 2×2 matrix: \( \lambda_1 + \lambda_2 = \text{trace}(A) \)

cards.front: How does the determinant relate to eigenvalues?
cards.back:
The determinant equals the product of the eigenvalues.

For a 2×2 matrix: \( \lambda_1 \times \lambda_2 = \det(A) \)

cards.front: What is the quick formula for 2×2 eigenvalues using mean \( m \) and product \( p \)?
cards.back:
If \( m = \frac{a+d}{2} \) and \( p = ad - bc \), then:

\( \lambda = m \pm \sqrt{m^2 - p} \)

The eigenvalues are: \( m + \sqrt{m^2 - p} \) and \( m - \sqrt{m^2 - p} \)

cards.front: Why is the mean-product formula useful?
cards.back:
It bypasses expanding the characteristic polynomial.

You can read \( m \) directly from the diagonal average and \( p \) from the determinant, then immediately compute eigenvalues.
